did.abstract: Records include registers; annual reports; administrative files; departmental minutes; admissions books containing details on admission, births, treatment, and disposition of patients; and photographs.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology records are open for research except for certain records restricted by statute or university policy.

The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology record group includes restricted material in the following categories:
Personnel Related Records -- Boxes 8
Patient/Client Records -- 2, 3, 8

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The history of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology parallels the history of the Medical School at the University of Michigan. Each dates from modest beginnings in 1850 and, after a series of travails in the nineteenth century, most fully realized their potential in the twentieth century. In the early years instruction was handled by Abram Sager and Alonzo Benjamin Palmer, each of whom taught other medical courses. As time passed medicine became more scientific and specialized, and the department came to offer more specific instruction. Edward Swift Dunster succeeded Sager in 1874 and oversaw the extension of Ob/Gyn lectures to a two-year course. Dunster saw his lectures as the basic foundation of medical education, but he was thwarted in his attempts to offer clinical instruction by the paucity of hospital births in Ann Arbor. James Nelson Martin, who came to head the department upon the death of Dunster in 1888, was similarly frustrated in his efforts to offer clinical experience to his interns.

It was not until the tenure of Reuben Peterson as chair of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology (1901-1931) that clinical instruction came to be a meaningful, integral part of instruction to aspiring Ob/Gyns. The rise of this sort of clinical instruction at the University of Michigan postdates its general use in American medical education; this owes more to the small-town nature of Ann Arbor than to any hide-bound medical practices of medical professors. Even with Peterson's tireless lobbying for more clinical, hands-on experience in maternity wards, it was not until 1910 that the Ob/Gyn interns saw as many as 100 births in any one year. After establishing the importance of clinical instruction (and insuring its practical use), Peterson then worked to have the Maternity Hospital made safer from sepsis. He finally succeeded in 1925 when the Maternity Ward opened in the new University Hospital, thus temporarily fulfilling the department's long-standing needs.

After Peterson's retirement in 1931, Norman F. Miller headed the department until 1964. In 1950 Miller oversaw the department's move to the new Women's Hospital which at the time "provided all available facilities for obstetrics as well as gynecology." Once again, time and changing medical practices outstripped the existing plant. During the chairmanship of J. Robert Willson (1964-1978) gynecology was handled in the main hospital, the Holden Perinatal Center was established to deal with high-risk pregnancies and newborn intensive care cases, and the department affiliated with Wayne County General Hospital to insure that students would acquire sufficient clinical experience. In 1990 Women's Hospital was moved to a new building to meet the contemporary needs of patients and doctors.

For a more detailed history of the University of Michigan Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology consult Obstetrics, Gynecology and the University of Michigan, by Richard W. Stander and Warren H. Pearse (privately published c. 1967). For information on the department during the tenure of J. Robert Willson (1964-1978), consult Willson's 1992 account, "The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the University of Michigan Medical School, 1964-1978," which is included with Willson's personal papers.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology document the evolution and development of this department, although the documentation is far from complete. The records primarily cover two periods: 1935-1958, and 1980-1995. The records are organized into nine series: Annual Reports; Minutes; Admissions Books/Birth Records; Registers and Miscellaneous Records; Administrative Files; Medical School Review Committee; Printed Material and Photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Annual Reports series, documents departmental activity, summarizing significant achievements for the period from 1985/86 to 1993/94. Reports for the years 1959-1978 are to be found in the papers of J. Robert Willson who served as chairman of the department from 1964 to 1978.

The series, Minutes contains two separate runs of minutes. The first run, covering 1950-1958, provides rich insight into the teaching and clinical activities of the department through notes on the twice-weekly meetings of staff. As these minutes are virtually contemporaneous with the peak years of the baby boom and the first generation of hospital birthing, they are especially interesting to historians. The second run covers the decade 1980-1990, and documents a department in transition operating under three different chairmen during this period.

Admissions Books, dating from 1935 to 1961, consists of ten ledgers of patient records which give details on admission, births, treatment, and disposition of patients within the department. The information in the first four volumes, titled Birth Records, was evidently compiled monthly and includes data on: name and age of mother, date and time of admission, method of delivery, episiotomy, doctor, discharge date; name, sex and birthweight of child, Kahn test, circumcision, discharge date, weight, and to whom, and complications. The monthly figures aggregate much of this data as well as provide information on average length of hospitalization. The information in the last six volumes, titled Annual Ledgers) was evidently entered as the patients were treated. These volumes contain further data on: length of pregnancy and labor, rupture of membranes, type of analgesia/ anesthesia, and a franker set of comments on complications. These records are closed for 100 years from the date of creation in order to protect patient's right of privacy. Please see "Patient Record Access Restriction Policies" for further information regarding these restrictions.

Registers and Miscellaneous Records, is an artificial series created around several "historical" files. These items date from the 1940s and 1950s although the information contained in the registers and lists dates from 1901 to 1979. Records include registers of visiting physicians, staff lists, clippings and material relating to the construction of the Women's Hospital in 1950, and brief notes on the activities of the Detroit and Michigan Ob/Gyn Societies.

odd.p: (includes records of Michigan and Detroit Ob/Gyn societies)

did.unittitle: Radio Talk: "What Is This Thing Called Change of Life?," Norman F. Miller 1952

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files series contains more contemporary documentation on the department, dating from 1980 to 1994, although the bulk of the material dates from 1985 to 1990. These records document resident training and the affiliated hospitals program, the department's physical facilities, as well as the development of departmental lectureships (Gosling Lectureship) and professorships (Norman F. Miller and J. Robert Willson professorships). Of note are the retreats which detail the relationship of the department to the overall Medical Center.

odd.p: (includes paper "The Legacy of Abram Sager," by Tommy N. Evans)

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series, consists of portraits of individual interns and residents from 1965 to 1979 arranged chronologically by year of matriculation, prints and negatives recording the construction of the Women's Hospital in 1950, and miscellaneous staff photographs. One photograph, in poor condition, includes the departmental staff from 1904 and features Drs. Peterson and Parmeter.

did.unittitle: Staff (group shot including Drs. Peterson and Parmeter) 1904

scopecontent.p: The Medical School Review Committee series includes a copy of the committees report as well as notes on committee meetings in which the strengths, weaknesses and needs of various Medical School departments are discussed. Department chairman Dr. Timothy Johnson headed the review committee.

did.unittitle: Committee Meeting Notes and Draft Report 1995

scopecontent.p: The Printed Materials series includes brochures, invitations, practitioner directories, and a program from the departmental reunion of 1956. There is also an obstetric manual from 1923/24 which accompanied a demonstration course.

did.unittitle: Residency in Obstetrics and Gynecology, circa 1986
The Sesquicentennial Years of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Michigan by George W. Morley, M.D., 2000

Ethics, Humanities and Law in Obstetrics and Gynecology, 1989
UMMC Obstetrics and Gynecology Faculty Retreat: Environmental Assessment, 1993

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Other materials related to obstetrics and gynecology can be found in the papers of Reuben Peterson and J. Robert Willson and in the records of the Ann Arbor Private Hospital which document women's health in Ann Arbor from 1902 to 1933. Use of the latter materials is also governed by the "Patient Record Access Agreement" of the Bentley Historical Library.
